pros: Fun, variety, nice clients and lovely coworkers
cons: Costumer service and demanding clients

pros: Giving back to the mental health community
cons: Pay is okay but salary needs to increase

pros: Interesting and dynamic place to work. Not always fair.
cons: Not always fair and is def exploitative of staff

pros: Flexible and great members on caseload
cons: Low Pay, no team support

pros: Location - eastern market has lots of food options
cons: Salary, benefits, professional development, career advancement, leadership, culture, communication

pros: They allow for a flexible schedule.
cons: The workload can be intense at times.

review_title: Good People, Low Pay, Large Often Stressful Caseload
job_title: Community Support Specialist in Washington, DC
pros: I like a lot of my coworkers. They are good caring people. My supervisor is great and I know some higher ups that I like a lot as well. Pretty humane place that encourages self-care and had absolutely zero pressure to go back to the office during Covid-19. For me it is also a convenient and pretty cool location right on Capitol Hill.
cons: The pay is kind of rough for this area. Also they do not do merit increases. HR states clearly that it is $2000 at your 2 year mark.and that is it. My position is low on the totem pole and as a result it is kind of a meat grinder. Most people only last less than a year. Also the caseloads can be up to 50 people which can be quite difficult to manage effectively sometimes.

pros: Coworkers are typically good and a saving grace
cons: Stress is extremely high, management is unhelpful and unconcerned about staff well-being, focus is on billable hours versus quality, necessary services. This results in extremely high turnover which affects clients poorly. Management doesn’t care about client well-being and is more concerned about billing and avoiding liability. Management is extremely disorganized, benefits are getting worse. Agency is going down fast. Pay is extremely low and no raises or wage increases. CEO is out of touch, dismissive and egotistical.

job_title: Behavioral Health Technician in Glendale, AZ
pros: Good learning experience about eating disorders
cons: Over worked and under paid

pros: The clients are great to work with.
cons: Low pay, low supervision, disorganized

job_title: Case Manager in Silver Spring, MD
pros: Great place to start your career
cons: No help or development from Management

pros: if you just need a job till you can find something better
cons: This organization is poorly run. The CEO is an egotistical racist who is stuck in the past. Her only focus is surrounding herself with people who will turn a blind eye to his dysfunction and mismanagement. Her only test is loyalty and competence is not needed as she believes she is the smartest person in every room. They exploit the people in need in the city to enrich themselves. Everything about this place is smoke and mirrors and the only real goal is to BILL, BILL, and BILL. They have stopped worrying about the best interest of their clients. If you are white you can excel. They lack diversity, except for exploiting recent graduates for their benefit. They pay the leadership team top wages and the staff who do the real work in the low 40s. They have no strategic plan, no focus, no vision, no organizational direction, and no purpose other than billing. You cannot succeed here unless you are white and complicit in organizational racism and a toxic work environment.

job_title: Community Support Worker in Washington, DC
pros: Learned a lot. Supportive coworkers. Connections with clients and make a difference in their lives.
cons: Very fast paced. High productivity standards. Not enough group supervision

pros: the people,the environment, great to be around everyday
cons: none that I can think of except certain people coming to late everyday effecting everyone else that worked there

review_title: Clients and staff great, managers not so much
pros: Food, paid holidays, year round work, health insurance
cons: Lack of training, gossiping, supervisors lack training, they make you feel replaceable

pros: The participants are the biggest pro. It is incredible to see them grow and learn new things and you are proud of yourself when you're the one to help them.
cons: The pay is okay starting however the company preaches to you when you start about opportunity for advancement in both the job and pay and that is completely not true. They will not give you a position advancement at all and you have to directly ask for more money and they will not give you what you deserve.

pros: Great people to work with!
cons: Low pay for the work .

pros: Awesome team, amazing experience, decent pay without needing social work degree
cons: Trial by fire type of training, huge workload, burnout, upper management that's clueless, etc.

pros: Clients, one on one, improvement
cons: Irregular schedules. Disorganized office and communication

review_title: Not a good company to work for!
pros: They'll hire anyone! So if you need a job apply.
cons: Culture, Pay and Poor Leadership and company doesn't truly care about staff. Benefits are weak.

job_title: Community Support Specialist in Washington, DC
pros: Supportive management, great advancement opportunities
cons: Excessive caseloads, no other cons

job_title: Clinical Care Coordinator in Washington, DC
pros: Coworkers and direct supervisors can be very supportive and understanding. You learn great hard skills that can be applied to pretty much any other job.
cons: Community Connections provides minimal training for new employees, and no follow-up training opportunities after you start your position. Safety of case managers is not a top priority - the work environment/building is very chaotic and unsafe and case workers are asked to go into unsafe neighborhoods alone. You are required to transport consumers in your personal vehicle and are not reimbursed for wear and tear. Turnover is high, the biggest reason being management's complete lack of interest in employee well-being. Leadership has also struggled through many failed restructuring attempts, with no communication to front-line staff. The  biggest priority for the agency is not the mission - it is making money. This translates to exceptionally low salary for staff,  overbearing case loads, and unreasonable productivity requirements.

review_title: Have had my ups and downs but overall this is a good company compared to similar options in the field.
pros: My experience with this company has been a case of you get out what you put in. Personally I have been given sufficient opportunities for advancement which I have really valued. Though I have not been there for a great deal of time I feel that I am given the opportunity to learn more and more about the work that we do on a frequent basis. Overall this is a good company and they really care about doing things right even when it's not always the easiest.
cons: Being a small company there's only so much room for growth. I feel that you have to work there for a good chunk of time before you really learn how to do your job. I have not always felt that the management is fair or reasonable with some of their policies. Almost no opportunities for learning outside of the company.

review_title: Great team and experience, yet hectic field work and non-competitive salaries
job_title: Community Support Worker- PSHP Team in Washington, DC
pros:
There were various benefits such as money for a cell phone bill or a cell phone provided, gas reimbursement, parking, healthcare, bonuses and tuition reimbursement. 
The teams were all cohesive and group and individual supervision was provided. 
Various teams with different specialized focus.
cons:
Negotiation for starting salary was deceitful, one number was offered but it was not disclosed that the number included "benefits" and the offer letter was more than $5,000 less than the verbal amount agreed upon at the verbal offer. 
Many had to drive their own vehicles and the gas reimbursement was not enough and not everyone was assisted with paying for the car insurance. 
The salary was less competitive than all of the other non-profits. 
High turnover rate and entry level positions seemed to target recent graduates.

pros: Passionate staff, being able to have positive impact on lives of individuals in need.
cons:
Unreasonably high demands put on staff, exceptionally low pay, Expected to work over 40 hours per week. Non-unionized and discouraged from unionizing.  

Very disorganized, constant changing of rules and regulations, constant staff burnout and turnover. 

Very little support available for staff, little regard for staff safety

Organization seems focused on quantity of care(productivity, billable hours) over the quality of care. Expectation is to complete 5 billable hours (productivity) per day. If you make 90% less than this quota at the end of the month you're put on probation, if you fall below 90% again within 6 months you are fired. I saw multiple staff let go because of this despite being excellent clinicians who cared deeply about the clients they serve.  
No support for licensure, no training opportunities, no CEU support. 

CEO, while very knowledgeable and a great practitioner, is remarkable out of touch regarding what the reality of community support entails.

job_title: Community Support Specialist in Washington, DC
pros: Supervision hours offered, fun clients, they try to increase moral with company gatherings, a good stepping stone, good vacation and sick leave policies
cons: office politics, poor management, favoritism, high turnover, poor salary, overall attitude that you can be replaced easily, focus on money making and not client care, use of personal vehicle to transport clients, demanding with focus on the negatives rather than the positive. The work demand is often done way into the evening with little respect to personal lives. Unrealistic expectations, lack of support and often put in dangerous situations both in the community and in the office. This is not a place you want to be for a long time.

pros: Great contact and experience with people with severe mental illness in the community.
cons: Unsafe environment in which to practice nursing, due to unrealistic expectations of the RN position by administration/management, and poor boundaries. Social workers with no medical background routinely try to call the shots regarding medication management, and ask nurses to coerce consumers in many ways in order to gain greater med compliance. The agency attempts to transcend the bureaucratic quagmire of DC Social Services, but they are part of the problem, too. Leadership has lost vision, and spends most of its time reacting to various dysfunctions. The rep is: "They set you up to fail, then when you fail, they blame you for it."

pros: Flexibility, many shifts avaliable because people are always wanting weekends off. Gives you experience with mentally ill patients.
cons: Almost no training on how to deal with and subdue patient outbursts or violent episodes. If injured on the job don't expect any support, they'll even try to pretend they don't need to pay your medical bills if you get a serious injury. You're on your own so if you're new and they stick you with a violent client you just have to pray it's an easy day. Management can barely cover shifts, other concerns are not important. No matter how many times clients get violent or run away they still get to stay in the program and do what they want. Having to cover for other people's shifts constantly is a given. Pay is less than $6 an hour for night shifts.

pros: Flexible scheduling, Access to competent supervisors, the ability to be innovative, and many opportunities to speak with upper management.
cons: While you can speak to management, they often do nothing with suggestions. There is a real lack of liability coverage and access to professional development opportunities. The productivity and paperwork requirements are very strict. Front line workers are expected to go above and beyond 100% of the time.  Also, there is no connection between departments. Many employees have no idea about all of the programs the organization offers.

pros:
-amazing coworkers, people aren't there for the money, they want to better the lives of others
-great supervisors
-get to work in the community, every day is different, gain familiarity with the city
-never boring- you'll remember this stuff for the rest of your life
-lots of laughs (okay this is to cope with the emotional stress, but still)
-some clients are really rewarding to work with, you develop meaningful relationships with them and staff
-opportunity for self growth/personal development
cons:
-exposure to dangerous situations. in the few years I was there, members of my team were sexually assaulted, physically assaulted, robbed, sued, threatened, you name it. sadly the agency does support or protect the staff from this. one director told me he wouldn't let his daughter work there, which speaks to the lack of safety in the workplace.
-I never heard of people getting raises and the pay is in the social worker range (side note- ACT does get paid more than regular case management, which is fair because they have the most intense clients)
-almost always work over 40 hours
-you need to have a car and you're on the road a lot. if you stay for more than a year and drive around a few hours a day, including to unsafe neighborhoods, the chances of getting in an accident or getting your car broken into are pretty high. those costs come out of your own pocket. also clients view you as a taxi and demand you drive them places.. most people agree to do this and bill it as building a therapeutic relationship but it's really just enabling them to be dependent on the agency
-high turnover, people get really burnt out.

job_title: Forensic Rehabilitation Specialist in Washington, DC
pros: Work is based in good intention and most staff truly care about their clients
cons:
In short:  Ridiculous productivity requirements nurture a culture which believes that Medicaid fraud is necessary for survival, and this fraudulence drives management to expect unrealistic productivity levels from all employees. With integrity, this job is difficult to perform - far more difficult than higher-ups are willing to compensate.

In long:
It is common knowledge and a barely tolerated issue among the workplace that this agency asks for far more than it is willing to give back to its employees. I may be one of the first in this agency to express this but I am certainly not the first or the last to know it: many case managers find that the only way to create the perception of thriving is to exaggerate their hours of productivity because productivity (hours billed to Medicaid) requirements are unrealistic when taking into account time for driving through DC traffic, waiting with clients, and finding parking spots (these can easily take up a couple of hours a day, combined).... this is essentially Medicaid fraud. It has become a culture in the workplace because it is seen as necessary to survive and keep the job. This is not because the employees are bad people or bad workers; it is known among employees that the productivity requirements of this job are simply not feasible unless the case manager/Rehabilitation Specialist puts in extra (unpaid, after hours) work to complete documentation requirements. Additionally, if an employee does not reach his/her productivity requirement, he/she is put on probation for six months, during which they cannot slip on productivity once without the risk of termination. It is this fear that drives fraudulence, and this fraudulence that drives management to expect more from employees.
No one in social work is in this field for the money, but the high amount of effort required to produce quality work with integrity and honesty would be do-able if employees were compensated at least according to the work they put in and if productivity requirements were lowered by even a half hour a day. 
I understand this is a non-profit organization and I understand it is difficult to receive the proper funding, but the idea of Medicaid fraud would not be such a culture in this workplace if employees were encouraged to produce quality work. The current attitude is "you've got to do what you've got to do" to get by, and all coworkers I have spoken to at my level find this agency unorganized and very unaware of the plight and survival habits of its lower-level employees.

job_title: Community Support Specialist in Washington, DC
pros: Great training opportunity - you will learn a ton, young like-minded workforce - it will influence you a lot in a positive way, stable non-profit, health benefits pretty good,
cons: Low boundaries with clients - they want you to do everything for them to chase the billing productivity; lack of clinical support (depending on supervisor); minimal advancement opportunities; low pay (32k-40k) for community support specialists - the bread and butter of the organization.

job_title: Community Support Specialist in Washington, DC
pros: Great supervisors and teammates.
cons: Pay is extremely low for the work you do. 32,500 to start as a CSS and a 2,400 stipend for your car. This does not cover parking tickets you will get since CC offers nor free parking for employees. Your work day will be 10-11 hours long due to driving and productivity requirements. YOU MUST HAVE 5 HOURS OF FACE TO FACE TIME DAILY with clients, or you will be terminated. I have been here 7 months and already 12 people (two supervisors) have left the agency.

pros: great work ethics, great Company to work for, benefits, sick and vacation leave, will keep you updated on all training needed for the position, staff meetings anytime staff want to have one and always get paid on time. do get raises not much, but you get one.
cons: Do not trust any of your co-workers, make sure you cover your back and do your work at all times. When coworkers make mistakes they blame it on you.

job_title: Community Support Specialist in Washington, DC
pros: I enjoyed working with my coworkers and my supervisor was great. Although the agency as a whole does not appear to care about the mental health of the staff, supervisor are more empathetic and yielding.
cons: Lack of communication throughout the agency, high expectations for the low compensation, no pay increase, wear and tear on personal vehicle, lots of paperwork.

pros: Flexible days, clients have interesting perspectives on life, will be able to do literally any human relations job with no sweat
cons: Terrible upper management, provides little support to lower staff, management lacks relevant insight to current street conditions, cm's are required to go into dangerous neighborhoods without prior training. The company clearly uses CM's as billing robots. Job is solely dependent on ability to bill clients for as much time as possible.

pros: Innovative, challenging, creative, with team work emphasized. Must be flexible and disciplined at the same time!
cons: Sometimes frustrating to work in an ever changing environment, but mental health is not a static entity in this culture!

pros: Flexible benefits, time, experience, free supervision, and good entry-level position. Cool work culture and team environment. Close to several health services.
